title: 110_s2784
content: The Howard M. Metzenbaum ``Menu Education and Labeling Act'' or the ``MEAL Act'' is the short title of this Act. The findings of the Act are also outlined. Congress finds that there is a strong link between diet and health, with diet-related diseases starting early in life. Increased caloric intake is a key factor contributing to the alarming increase in obesity in the United States. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2/3 of American adults are overweight or obese, and the rates of obesity have doubled in children and tripled in teens since 1980. Obesity increases the risk of diabetes and heart disease. The rates of obesity have doubled in children and tripled in teens since 1980. Obesity increases the risk of diabetes, heart disease, stroke, cancer, and other health problems. The annual cost of obesity in the United States is $117 billion. There has been a significant increase in meals prepared or eaten outside the home, with a third of calories and almost half of total food dollars spent on food from restaurants and food-service establishments. Excess saturated fat intake is a major risk factor for heart disease, the leading cause of death in the United States. Heart disease also leads to significant healthcare expenditures and lost productivity, totaling $142 billion in 2005. Increased sodium intake is linked to high blood pressure. Increased sodium intake is associated with a higher risk of high blood pressure, which can lead to cardiovascular disease, especially stroke. The proportion of adults with high blood pressure increases with age, reaching 45% at age 50, 60% at age 60, and over 70% at age 70. The Nutrition Labeling and Education Act of 1990 requires nutrition information on packaged foods, but restaurant foods are exempt from these requirements. Approximately 75 percent of adults use food labels on packaged foods, leading to healthier diets. Nutrition information on labels influences about half of people to change their food purchasing decisions. Consumers find it challenging to control calorie intake at restaurants due to limited nutrition information availability. Consumers struggle to limit calorie intake at restaurants due to limited nutrition information availability. Studies suggest consumers want nutrition information when ordering food to make informed decisions. Surgeon General and Secretary of Health recommend increased availability of nutrition information to reduce obesity. Nutrition labeling of standard menu items at chain restaurants is required. Section 403(q)(5) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to include provisions for restaurants and retail food establishments regarding nutrition labeling of standard menu items at chain restaurants. Restaurants and Retail Food Establishments with 20 or more locations under the same trade name must disclose nutrition information for standard menu items. Restaurants and Retail Food Establishments with 20 or more locations must disclose the number of calories, saturated fat plus trans fat, and sodium in standard menu items. Restaurants and Retail Food Establishments with 20 or more locations must provide clear and conspicuous nutrition information, including calorie counts, on menus or signs for standard menu items. Restaurants and Retail Food Establishments with 20 or more locations must provide clear and conspicuous nutrition information, including calorie counts, on menus or signs for standard menu items. The information must be provided in writing upon request of a prospective purchaser. This requirement does not apply to items not listed on a menu. The clause does not apply to items not listed on a menu, such as condiments, daily specials, or self-service facilities like salad bars. At self-service facilities like salad bars, restaurants must display calorie information for each food item offered. Retail food establishments can also provide additional nutrition information voluntarily, as long as it complies with labeling requirements. Retail food establishments can voluntarily provide nutrition information that complies with labeling requirements, and state or local requirements may also apply. Proposed regulations must be implemented within one year of enactment. The Secretary must promulgate proposed regulations within 1 year of enactment to allow for variations in serving sizes and food preparation due to human error and other factors. Final regulations must be in place within 2 years. The Secretary must promulgate final regulations within 2 years of enactment to implement variations in serving sizes and food preparation. If final regulations are not issued by the required date, the proposed regulations will become effective. The final regulations for vending machines must be issued within 2 years of enactment, and if not, the proposed regulations will become effective as final regulations the day after. The Secretary will publish notice of the final regulations in the Federal Register. The vending machine operator must provide a sign near the article disclosing the number of calories if the vending machine does not allow examination of the article before purchase and is operated by a business owning 20 or more vending machines. The vending machine operator can voluntarily provide additional nutrition information if it complies with labeling requirements. State or local regulations do not prevent this. The Secretary must propose regulations within 1 year and finalize them within 2 years to implement nutrition information requirements for vending machine operators. The Secretary must propose and finalize regulations within 2 years to implement nutrition information requirements for vending machine operators. If final regulations are not issued by the required date, proposed regulations will be in effect. The final regulations must be proposed and finalized within 2 years for vending machine operators to implement nutrition information requirements. If final regulations are not issued by the deadline, proposed regulations will automatically become effective.
